snippet: Court hearings meant to protect New York homeowners from foreclosure are hopelessly slowed by endless paperwork and requests for additional information.
abstract: New York has been aggressive in trying to protect homeowners from foreclosure, turning courts into teeming negotiation centers working to keep people in their homes; four years into the foreclosure crisis, however, the state's courts are largely at a stalemate, facing a record number of cases and the endless bureaucracy of special settlement conferences, the core of the state's approach to the crisis; lawyers and officials say New York’s experience shows the limits of a state’s ability to cope with the national foreclosure morass.
lead_paragraph: Court hearings meant to protect New York homeowners from foreclosure are hopelessly slowed by endless paperwork and requests for additional information.

headline.seo: Push to Avert Foreclosures Hits Court Logjam
headline.main: Push to Avert Foreclosures Hits Court Logjam
headline.print_headline: Round and Round in the Paper Chase of Foreclosure Court
